node.name: nat
node.description: NAT moduleNone

node.name: instances
node.description: NAT instancesNone

node.name: instance
node.description: A NAT instance. This identifier can be automatically assigned or explicitly configured.None

node.name: id
node.description:
NAT instance identifier.
The identifier must be greater than zero.None

node.name: name
node.description: A name associated with the NAT instance.None

node.name: enable
node.description: Status of the NAT instance.None

node.name: capabilities
node.description: NAT capabilities.None

node.name: nat-flavor
node.description: Supported translation type(s).None

node.name: per-interface-binding
node.description: Indicates the capability of a NAT to associate a particular NAT session not only with the five tuples used for the transport connection on both sides of the NAT but also with the internal interface on which the user device is connected to the NAT.None

node.name: transport-protocols
node.description: List of supported protocols.None

node.name: protocol-id
node.description:
The upper-layer protocol associated with a mapping.
Values are taken from the IANA Protocol Numbers registry.
For example, this field contains 6 for TCP, 17 for UDP, 33 for DCCP, or 132 for SCTP.None

node.name: protocol-name
node.description:
The name of the upper-layer protocol associated with this mapping.
For example, TCP, UDP, DCCP, and SCTP.None

node.name: restricted-port-support
node.description: Indicates source port NAT restriction support.None

node.name: static-mapping-support
node.description: Indicates whether static mappings are supported.None

node.name: port-randomization-support
node.description: Indicates whether port randomization is supported.None

node.name: port-range-allocation-support
node.description: Indicates whether port range allocation is supported.None

node.name: port-preservation-suport
node.description: Indicates whether port preservation is supported.None

node.name: port-parity-preservation-support
node.description: Indicates whether port parity preservation is supported.None

node.name: address-roundrobin-support
node.description: Indicates whether address allocation round robin is supported.None

node.name: paired-address-pooling-support
node.description: Indicates whether paired-address-pooling is supportedNone

node.name: endpoint-independent-mapping-support
node.description: Indicates whether endpoint-independent- mapping is supported.None

node.name: address-dependent-mapping-support
node.description: Indicates whether address-dependent-mapping is supported.None

node.name: address-and-port-dependent-mapping-support
node.description: Indicates whether address-and-port-dependent-mapping is supported.None

node.name: endpoint-independent-filtering-support
node.description: Indicates whether endpoint-independent-filtering is supported.None

node.name: address-dependent-filtering
node.description: Indicates whether address-dependent-filtering is supported.None

node.name: address-and-port-dependent-filtering
node.description: Indicates whether address-and-port-dependent is supported.None

node.name: fragment-behavior
node.description: The fragment behavior is the NAT instance's capability to translate fragments received on the external interface of the NAT.None

node.name: type
node.description:
Specify the translation type. Particularly useful when multiple translation flavors are supported.
If one type is supported by a NAT, this parameter is by default set to that type.None

node.name: per-interface-binding
node.description:
A NAT that associates a particular NAT session not only with the five tuples used for the transport connection on both sides of the NAT but also with the internal interface on which the user device is connected to the NAT.
If supported, this mode of operation should be configurable, and it should be disabled by default in general-purpose NAT devices. If one single per-interface binding behavior is supported by a NAT, this parameter is by default set to that behavior.None

node.name: nat-pass-through
node.description: IP prefix NAT pass-through.None

node.name: id
node.description: An identifier of the IP prefix pass-through.None

node.name: prefix
node.description:
The IP addresses that match should not be translated.
It must be possible to administratively turn off translation for specific destination addresses and/or ports.None

node.name: port
node.description:
It must be possible to administratively turn off translation for specific destination addresses and/or ports.
If no prefix is defined, the NAT pass-through bound to a given port applies for any destination address.None

node.name: policy
node.description: NAT parameters for a given instanceNone

node.name: id
node.description: An identifier of the NAT policy. It must be unique within the NAT instance.None

node.name: clat-parameters
node.description: CLAT parameters.None

node.name: clat-ipv6-prefixes
node.description: 464XLAT double-translation treatment is stateless when a dedicated /64 is available for translation on the CLAT. Otherwise, the CLAT will have both stateful and stateless translation since it requires NAT44 from the LAN to a single IPv4 address and then stateless translation to a single IPv6 address.None

node.name: ipv6-prefix
node.description: An IPv6 prefix used for CLAT.None

node.name: ipv4-prefixes
node.description: Pool of IPv4 addresses used for CLAT. 192.0.0.0/29 is the IPv4 service continuity prefix.None

node.name: ipv4-prefix
node.description:
464XLAT double-translation treatment is stateless when a dedicated /64 is available for translation on the CLAT. Otherwise, the CLAT will have both stateful and stateless translation since it requires NAT44 from the LAN to a single IPv4 address and then stateless translation to a single IPv6 address. The CLAT performs NAT44 for all IPv4 LAN packets so that all the LAN-originated IPv4 packets appear from a single IPv4 address and are then statelessly translated to one interface IPv6 address that is claimed by the CLAT.
An IPv4 address from this pool is also provided to an application that makes use of literals.None

node.name: nptv6-prefixes
node.description:
Provides one or a list of (internal IPv6 prefix, external IPv6 prefix) required for NPTv6.
In its simplest form, NPTv6 interconnects two network links: one is an 'internal' network link attached to a leaf network within a single administrative domain, and the other is an 'external' network with connectivity to the global Internet.None

node.name: internal-ipv6-prefix
node.description: An IPv6 prefix used by an internal interface of NPTv6.None

node.name: external-ipv6-prefix
node.description: An IPv6 prefix used by the external interface of NPTv6.None

node.name: eam
node.description:
The Explicit Address Mapping Table is a conceptual table in which each row represents an EAM.
Each EAM describes a mapping between IPv4 and IPv6 prefixes/addresses.None

node.name: ipv4-prefix
node.description: The IPv4 prefix of an EAM.None

node.name: ipv6-prefix
node.description: The IPv6 prefix of an EAM.None

node.name: nat64-prefixes
node.description: Provides one or a list of NAT64 prefixes with or without a list of destination IPv4 prefixes. It allows mapping IPv4 address ranges to IPv6 prefixes. For example: 192.0.2.0/24 is mapped to 2001:db8:122:300::/56. 198.51.100.0/24 is mapped to 2001:db8:122::/48.None

node.name: nat64-prefix
node.description:
A NAT64 prefix. Can be a Network-Specific Prefix (NSP) or a Well-Known Prefix (WKP).
Organizations deploying stateless IPv4/IPv6 translation should assign an NSP to their IPv4/IPv6 translation service. For stateless NAT64, IPv4-translatable IPv6 addresses must use the selected NSP.
Both IPv4-translatable IPv6 addresses and IPv4-converted IPv6 addresses should use the same prefix.None

node.name: destination-ipv4-prefix
node.description: An IPv4 prefix/address.None

node.name: ipv4-prefix
node.description: An IPv4 address/prefix.None

node.name: stateless-enable
node.description: Enable explicitly stateless NAT64.None

node.name: external-ip-address-pool
node.description:
Pool of external IP addresses used to service internal hosts.
A pool is a set of IP prefixes.None

node.name: pool-id
node.description:
An identifier that uniquely identifies the address pool within a NAT instance.
The identifier must be greater than zero.None

node.name: external-ip-pool
node.description: An IPv4 prefix used for NAT purposes.None

node.name: port-set-restrict
node.description:
Configures contiguous and non-contiguous port ranges.
The port set is used to restrict the external source port numbers used by the translator.None

node.name: port-type
node.description: Port type: port-range or port-set-algo.None

node.name: start-port-number
node.description: Beginning of the port range.None

node.name: end-port-number
node.description: End of the port range.None

node.name: psid-offset
node.description:
The number of offset bits (a.k.a., 'a' bits). Specifies the numeric value for the excluded port range/offset bits.
Allowed values are between 0 and 15.None

node.name: psid-len
node.description:
The length of PSID, representing the sharing ratio for an IPv4 address.
(also known as 'k').
The address-sharing ratio would be 2^k.None

node.name: psid
node.description: PSID value, which identifies a set of ports algorithmically.None

node.name: dst-nat-enable
node.description:
Enable/disable Destination NAT.
A NAT44 may be configured to enable Destination NAT, too.None

node.name: dst-ip-address-pool
node.description: Pool of IP addresses used for Destination NAT.None

node.name: pool-id
node.description: An identifier of the address pool.None

node.name: dst-in-ip-pool
node.description: Is used to identify an internal destination IP prefix/address to be translated.None

node.name: dst-out-ip-pool
node.description: IP address/prefix used for Destination NAT.None

node.name: transport-protocols
node.description:
Configure the transport protocols to be handled by the translator.
TCP and UDP are supported by default.None

node.name: protocol-id
node.description:
The upper-layer protocol associated with this mapping.
Values are taken from the IANA Protocol Numbers registry.
For example, this field contains 6 for TCP, 17 for UDP, 33 for DCCP, or 132 for SCTP.None

node.name: protocol-name
node.description:
The name of the upper-layer protocol associated with this mapping.
For example, TCP, UDP, DCCP, and SCTP.None

node.name: subscriber-mask-v6
node.description:
The subscriber mask is an integer that indicates the length of significant bits to be applied on the source IPv6 address (internal side) to unambiguously identify a user device (e.g., CPE).
Subscriber mask is a system-wide configuration parameter that is used to enforce generic per-subscriber policies (e.g., port-quota).
The enforcement of these generic policies does not require the configuration of every subscriber's prefix.
Example: suppose the 2001:db8:100:100::/56 prefix is assigned to a NAT64-serviced CPE. Suppose also that 2001:db8:100:100::1 is the IPv6 address used by the client that resides in that CPE. When the NAT64 receives a packet from this client, it applies the subscriber-mask-v6 (e.g., 56) on the source IPv6 address to compute the associated prefix for this client (2001:db8:100:100::/56). Then, the NAT64 enforces policies based on that prefix (2001:db8:100:100::/56), not on the exact source IPv6 address.None

node.name: subscriber-match
node.description: IP prefix match. A subscriber is identified by a subnet.None

node.name: match-id
node.description: An identifier of the subscriber match.None

node.name: subnet
node.description: The IP address subnets that match should be translated. For example, all addresses that belong to the 192.0.2.0/24 prefix must be processed by the NAT.None

node.name: address-allocation-type
node.description: Specifies how external IP addresses are allocated.None

node.name: port-allocation-type
node.description: Indicates the type of port allocation.None

node.name: mapping-type
node.description: Indicates the type of NAT mapping.None

node.name: filtering-type
node.description: Indicates the type of NAT filtering.None

node.name: fragment-behavior
node.description: The fragment behavior instructs the NAT about the behavior to follow to translate fragments received on the external interface of the NAT.None

node.name: port-quota
node.description: Configures a port quota to be assigned per subscriber. It corresponds to the maximum number of ports to be used by a subscriber.None

node.name: port-limit
node.description: Configures a port quota to be assigned per subscriber. It corresponds to the maximum number of ports to be used by a subscriber.None

node.name: quota-type
node.description: Indicates whether the port quota applies to all protocols (0) or to a specific protocol.None

node.name: port-set
node.description: Manages port-set assignments.None

node.name: port-set-size
node.description: Indicates the size of assigned port sets.None

node.name: port-set-timeout
node.description: inactivity timeout for port sets.None

node.name: timers
node.description: Configure values of various timeouts.None

node.name: udp-timeout
node.description: UDP inactivity timeout. That is the time a mapping will stay active without packets traversing the NAT.None

node.name: tcp-idle-timeout
node.description: TCP idle timeout should be 2 hours and 4 minutes.None

node.name: tcp-trans-open-timeout
node.description:
The value of the transitory open connection idle-timeout.
A NAT should provide different configurable parameters for configuring the open and closing idle timeouts.
To accommodate deployments that consider a partially open timeout of 4 minutes as being excessive from a security standpoint, a NAT may allow the configured timeout to be less than 4 minutes.
However, a minimum default transitory connection idle-timeout of 4 minutes is recommended.None

node.name: tcp-trans-close-timeout
node.description:
The value of the transitory close connection idle-timeout.
A NAT should provide different configurable parameters for configuring the open and closing idle timeouts.None

node.name: tcp-in-syn-timeout
node.description: A NAT must not respond to an unsolicited inbound SYN packet for at least 6 seconds after the packet is received. If during this interval the NAT receives and translates an outbound SYN for the connection the NAT must silently drop the original unsolicited inbound SYN packet.None

node.name: fragment-min-timeout
node.description: As long as the NAT has available resources, the NAT allows the fragments to arrive over the fragment-min-timeout interval. The default value is inspired from RFC 6146.None

node.name: icmp-timeout
node.description: An ICMP Query session timer must not expire in less than 60 seconds. It is recommended that the ICMP Query session timer be made configurableNone

node.name: per-port-timeout
node.description: Some NATs are configurable with short timeouts for some ports, e.g., as 10 seconds on port 53 (DNS) and 123 (NTP), and longer timeouts on other ports.None

node.name: port-number
node.description: A port number.None

node.name: protocol
node.description:
The upper-layer protocol associated with this port.
Values are taken from the IANA Protocol Numbers registry.
If no protocol is indicated, it means 'any protocol'.None

node.name: timeout
node.description: Timeout for this port numberNone

node.name: hold-down-timeout
node.description:
Hold-down timer.
Ports in the hold-down pool are not reassigned until hold-down-timeout expires.
The length of time and the maximum number of ports in this state must be configurable by the administrator.
This is necessary in order to prevent collisions between old and new mappings and sessions. It ensures that all established sessions are broken instead of redirected to a different peer.None

node.name: hold-down-max
node.description: Maximum ports in the hold-down port pool.None

node.name: fragments-limit
node.description: Limits the number of out-of-order fragments that can be handled.None

node.name: algs
node.description: Features related to the Application Layer Gateway (ALG).None

node.name: name
node.description: The name of the ALG.None

node.name: transport-protocol
node.description: The transport protocol used by the ALG (e.g., TCP and UDP).None

node.name: dst-transport-port
node.description: The destination port number(s) used by the ALG. For example, - 21 for the FTP ALG - 53 for the DNS ALG.None

node.name: start-port-number
node.description: Beginning of the port range.None

node.name: end-port-number
node.description: End of the port range.None

node.name: src-transport-port
node.description: The source port number(s) used by the ALG.None

node.name: start-port-number
node.description: Beginning of the port range.None

node.name: end-port-number
node.description: End of the port range.None

node.name: status
node.description: Enable/disable the ALG.None

node.name: all-algs-enable
node.description:
Disable/enable all ALGs.
When specified, this parameter overrides the one that may be indicated, eventually, by the 'status' of an individual ALG.None

node.name: notify-pool-usage
node.description: Notification of pool usage when certain criteria are met.None

node.name: pool-id
node.description: Pool-ID for which the notification criteria is definedNone

node.name: low-threshold
node.description:
Notification must be generated when the defined low threshold is reached.
For example, if a notification is required when the pool utilization reaches below 10%, this configuration parameter must be set to 10.
0% indicates that low-threshold notification is disabled.None

node.name: high-threshold
node.description:
Notification must be generated when the defined high threshold is reached.
For example, if a notification is required when the pool utilization reaches 90%, this configuration parameter must be set to 90.
Setting the same value as low-threshold is equivalent to disabling high-threshold notification.None

node.name: notify-interval
node.description: Minimum number of seconds between successive notifications for this pool.None

node.name: external-realm
node.description: Identifies the external realm of the NAT instance.None

node.name: realm-type
node.description: Can be an interface, VRF instance, etc.None

node.name: interface
node.description: External interface.None

node.name: external-interface
node.description: Name of the external interface.None

node.name: dslite:max-softwires-per-subscriber
node.description:
Configures the maximum softwires per subscriber feature.
A subscriber is uniquely identified by means of a subscriber-mask (subscriber-mask-v6).
This policy aims to prevent a misbehaving subscriber from mounting several DS-Lite softwires that would consume additional AFTR resources (e.g., get more external ports if the quota was enforced on a per-softwire basis and consume extra processing due to a large number of active softwires).None

node.name: dslite:state-migrate
node.description:
State migration is enabled by default.
In the event a new IPv6 address is assigned to the B4 element, the AFTR should migrate existing state to be bound to the new IPv6 address. This operation ensures that traffic destined to the previous B4's IPv6 address will be redirected to the newer B4's IPv6 address. The destination IPv6 address for tunneling return traffic from the AFTR should be the last seen as the B4's IPv6 source address from the user device (e.g., CPE).
The AFTR uses the subscriber-mask-v6 to determine whether two IPv6 addresses belong to the same CPE (e.g., if the subscriber-mask-v6 is set to 56, the AFTR concludes that 2001:db8:100:100::1 and 2001:db8:100:100::2 belong to the same CPE assigned with 2001:db8:100:100::/56).None

node.name: dslite:b4-address-change-limit
node.description:
Minimum number of seconds between a successive B4's IPv6 address change from the same prefix.
Changing the source B4's IPv6 address may be used as an attack vector. Packets with a new B4's IPv6 address from the same prefix should be rate-limited.
It is recommended that this rate limit be set to 30 minutes; other values can be set on a per-deployment basis.None

node.name: dslite:mss-clamping
node.description: MSS rewriting configuration to avoid IPv6 fragmentation.None

node.name: dslite:enable
node.description: Enable/disable MSS rewriting feature.None

node.name: dslite:mss-value
node.description: Sets the MSS value to be used for MSS rewriting.None

node.name: mapping-limits
node.description: Information about the configuration parameters that limits the mappings based upon various criteria.None

node.name: limit-subscribers
node.description:
Maximum number of subscribers that can be serviced by a NAT instance.
A subscriber is identified by a given prefix.None

node.name: limit-address-mappings
node.description:
Maximum number of address mappings that can be handled by a NAT instance.
When this limit is reached, packets that would normally trigger translation will be dropped.None

node.name: limit-port-mappings
node.description:
Maximum number of port mappings that can be handled by a NAT instance.
When this limit is reached, packets that would normally trigger translation will be dropped.None

node.name: limit-per-protocol
node.description: Configure limits per transport protocolNone

node.name: protocol-id
node.description:
The upper-layer protocol.
Values are taken from the IANA Protocol Numbers registry.
For example, this field contains 6 for TCP, 17 for UDP, 33 for DCCP, or 132 for SCTP.None

node.name: limit
node.description: Maximum number of protocol-specific NAT mappings per instance.None

node.name: connection-limits
node.description: Information about the configuration parameters that rate-limit the translation based upon various criteria.None

node.name: limit-per-subscriber
node.description: Rate-limit the number of new mappings and sessions per subscriber.None

node.name: limit-per-instance
node.description: Rate-limit the number of new mappings and sessions per instance.None

node.name: limit-per-protocol
node.description: Configure limits per transport protocolNone

node.name: protocol-id
node.description:
The upper-layer protocol.
Values are taken from the IANA Protocol Numbers registry.
For example, this field contains 6 for TCP, 17 for UDP, 33 for DCCP, or 132 for SCTP.None

node.name: limit
node.description: Limit the number of protocol-specific mappings and sessions per instance.None

node.name: notification-limits
node.description: Sets notification limits.None

node.name: notify-interval
node.description: Minimum number of seconds between successive notifications for this NAT instance.None

node.name: notify-addresses-usage
node.description:
Notification of address mappings usage over the whole NAT instance.
Notification must be generated when the defined threshold is reached.
For example, if a notification is required when the address mappings utilization reaches 90%, this configuration parameter must be set to 90.None

node.name: notify-ports-usage
node.description:
Notification of port mappings usage over the whole NAT instance.
Notification must be generated when the defined threshold is reached.
For example, if a notification is required when the port mappings utilization reaches 90%, this configuration parameter must be set to 90.None

node.name: notify-subscribers-limit
node.description:
Notification of active subscribers per NAT instance.
Notification must be generated when the defined threshold is reached.None

node.name: mapping-table
node.description: NAT mapping table. Applicable for functions that maintain static and/or dynamic mappings, such as NAT44, Destination NAT, NAT64, or CLAT.None

node.name: mapping-entry
node.description: NAT mapping entry.None

node.name: index
node.description: A unique identifier of a mapping entry. This identifier can be automatically assigned by the NAT instance or be explicitly configured.None

node.name: type
node.description: Indicates the type of a mapping entry. For example, a mapping can be: static, implicit dynamic, or explicit dynamic.None

node.name: transport-protocol
node.description:
The upper-layer protocol associated with this mapping. Values are taken from the IANA Protocol Numbers registry: &lthttps://www.iana.org/assignments/protocol-numbers/&gt.
For example, this field contains 6 for TCP, 17 for UDP, 33 for DCCP, or 132 for SCTP.
If this leaf is not instantiated, then the mapping applies to any protocol.None

node.name: internal-src-address
node.description: Corresponds to the source IPv4/IPv6 address/prefix of the packet received on an internal interface.None

node.name: internal-src-port
node.description:
Corresponds to the source port of the packet received on an internal interface.
It is also used to indicate the internal source ICMP identifier.
As a reminder, all the ICMP Query messages contain an 'Identifier' field, which is referred to in this document as the 'ICMP Identifier'.None

node.name: start-port-number
node.description: Beginning of the port range.None

node.name: end-port-number
node.description: End of the port range.None

node.name: external-src-address
node.description: Source IP address/prefix of the packet sent on an external interface of the NAT.None

node.name: external-src-port
node.description:
Source port of the packet sent on an external interface of the NAT.
It is also used to indicate the external source ICMP identifier.None

node.name: start-port-number
node.description: Beginning of the port range.None

node.name: end-port-number
node.description: End of the port range.None

node.name: internal-dst-address
node.description:
Corresponds to the destination IP address/prefix of the packet received on an internal interface of the NAT.
For example, some NAT implementations support the translation of both source and destination addresses and port numbers, sometimes referred to as 'Twice NAT'.None

node.name: internal-dst-port
node.description:
Corresponds to the destination port of the IP packet received on the internal interface.
It is also used to include the internal destination ICMP identifier.None

node.name: start-port-number
node.description: Beginning of the port range.None

node.name: end-port-number
node.description: End of the port range.None

node.name: external-dst-address
node.description: Corresponds to the destination IP address/prefix of the packet sent on an external interface of the NAT.None

node.name: external-dst-port
node.description:
Corresponds to the destination port number of the packet sent on the external interface of the NAT.
It is also used to include the external destination ICMP identifier.None

node.name: start-port-number
node.description: Beginning of the port range.None

node.name: end-port-number
node.description: End of the port range.None

node.name: lifetime
node.description:
When specified, it is used to track the connection that is fully formed (e.g., once the three-way handshake TCP is completed) or the duration for maintaining an explicit mapping alive. The mapping entry will be removed by the NAT instance once this lifetime is expired.
When reported in a get operation, the lifetime indicates the remaining validity lifetime.
Static mappings may not be associated with a lifetime. If no lifetime is associated with a static mapping, an explicit action is required to remove that mapping.None

node.name: dslite:b4-ipv6-address
node.description: Records the IPv6 address used by a B4 element and the last time that address changed.None

node.name: dslite:address
node.description: Corresponds to the IPv6 address used by a B4 element.None

node.name: dslite:last-address-change
node.description: Records the last time that the address changed.None

node.name: dslite:v6-dscp
node.description: DSCP value used at the softwire level (i.e., IPv6 header).None

node.name: dslite:internal-v4-dscp
node.description: DSCP value of the encapsulated IPv4 packet.None

node.name: dslite:external-v4-dscp
node.description: DSCP value of the translated IPv4 packet as marked by the AFTR.None

node.name: statistics
node.description: Statistics related to the NAT instance.None

node.name: discontinuity-time
node.description: The time on the most recent occasion at which the NAT instance suffered a discontinuity. This must be initialized when the NAT instance is configured or rebooted.None

node.name: traffic-statistics
node.description: Generic traffic statistics.None

node.name: sent-packets
node.description: Number of packets sent.None

node.name: sent-bytes
node.description: Counter for sent traffic in bytes.None

node.name: rcvd-packets
node.description: Number of received packets.None

node.name: rcvd-bytes
node.description: Counter for received traffic in bytes.None

node.name: dropped-packets
node.description: Number of dropped packets.None

node.name: dropped-bytes
node.description: Counter for dropped traffic in bytes.None

node.name: dropped-fragments
node.description: Number of dropped fragments on the external realm.None

node.name: dropped-address-limit-packets
node.description: Number of dropped packets because an address limit is reached.None

node.name: dropped-address-limit-bytes
node.description: Counter of dropped packets because an address limit is reached, in bytes.None

node.name: dropped-address-packets
node.description: Number of dropped packets because no address is available for allocation.None

node.name: dropped-address-bytes
node.description: Counter of dropped packets because no address is available for allocation, in bytes.None

node.name: dropped-port-limit-packets
node.description: Number of dropped packets because a port limit is reached.None

node.name: dropped-port-limit-bytes
node.description: Counter of dropped packets because a port limit is reached, in bytes.None

node.name: dropped-port-packets
node.description: Number of dropped packets because no port is available for allocation.None

node.name: dropped-port-bytes
node.description: Counter of dropped packets because no port is available for allocation, in bytes.None

node.name: dropped-subscriber-limit-packets
node.description: Number of dropped packets because the subscriber limit per instance is reached.None

node.name: dropped-subscriber-limit-bytes
node.description: Counter of dropped packets because the subscriber limit per instance is reached, in bytes.None

node.name: mappings-statistics
node.description: Mappings statistics.None

node.name: total-active-subscribers
node.description:
Total number of active subscribers (that is, subscribers for which the NAT maintains active mappings).
A subscriber is identified by a subnet, subscriber-mask, etc.None

node.name: total-address-mappings
node.description: Total number of address mappings present at a given time. It includes both static and dynamic mappings.None

node.name: total-port-mappings
node.description: Total number of NAT port mappings present at a given time. It includes both static and dynamic mappings.None

node.name: total-per-protocol
node.description: Total mappings for each enabled/supported protocol.None

node.name: protocol-id
node.description: The upper-layer protocol. For example, this field contains 6 for TCP, 17 for UDP, 33 for DCCP, or 132 for SCTP.None

node.name: total
node.description: Total number of a protocol-specific mappings present at a given time. The protocol is identified by protocol-id.None

node.name: dslite:active-softwires
node.description: The number of currently active softwires on the AFTR instance.None

node.name: pools-stats
node.description: Statistics related to address/prefix pools usageNone

node.name: addresses-allocated
node.description: Number of all allocated addresses.None

node.name: addresses-free
node.description: Number of unallocated addresses of all pools at a given time. The sum of unallocated and allocated addresses is the total number of addresses of the pools.None

node.name: ports-stats
node.description: Statistics related to port numbers usage.None

node.name: ports-allocated
node.description: Number of allocated ports from all pools.None

node.name: ports-free
node.description: Number of unallocated addresses from all pools.None

node.name: per-pool-stats
node.description: Statistics related to address/prefix pool usageNone

node.name: pool-id
node.description: Unique identifier that represents a pool of addresses/prefixes.None

node.name: discontinuity-time
node.description: The time on the most recent occasion at which this pool counter suffered a discontinuity. This must be initialized when the address pool is configured.None

node.name: pool-stats
node.description: Statistics related to address/prefix pool usageNone

node.name: addresses-allocated
node.description: Number of allocated addresses from this pool.None

node.name: addresses-free
node.description: Number of unallocated addresses in this pool.None

node.name: port-stats
node.description: Statistics related to port numbers usage.None

node.name: ports-allocated
node.description: Number of allocated ports from this pool.None

node.name: ports-free
node.description: Number of unallocated addresses from this pool.None

node.name: nat-pool-event
node.description: Notifications must be generated when the defined high/low threshold is reached. Related configuration parameters must be provided to trigger the notifications.None

node.name: id
node.description: NAT instance identifier.None

node.name: policy-id
node.description: Policy identifier.None

node.name: pool-id
node.description: Pool Identifier.None

node.name: notify-pool-threshold
node.description: A threshold (high threshold or low threshold) has been fired.None

node.name: nat-instance-event
node.description: Notifications must be generated when notify-addresses-usage and/or notify-ports-usage thresholds are reached.None

node.name: id
node.description: NAT instance identifier.None

node.name: notify-subscribers-threshold
node.description: The notify-subscribers-limit threshold has been fired.None

node.name: notify-addresses-threshold
node.description: The notify-addresses-usage threshold has been fired.None

node.name: notify-ports-threshold
node.description: The notify-ports-usage threshold has been fired.None
